column4: how do i find a file using terminal...im trying to find a file called myfile.txt  i do find myfile.txt and it says it didnt find anything i know its in the system somewhere
find / -name myfile.txt -print 2>/dev/null
why -print 2>/dev/null
why -print 2>/dev/null
it will send the errors you get due to not having read permissions on files, to a null bucket
ooh ok thank you fego
how do i make it scan the whole system? and all its subdirectories... i did the command and im 1000% certain its not going in deep enuff in the ssytem
the above command line will search the whole system starting from the / dir
and its child dirs
well for example fego i did ..  find / -iname *.desktop and it returned only a few *.desktop files and i know theres way more i dont get whats up
why -iname ? just simply -name
just in case theres uppercases..i want find to ignore if its upper cases
Recent versions of GNU find seem to have an -iname flag, for case-insensitive name search.
yeah exactly...if the file name is MyFile.txt ..using -iname myfile.txt will find MyFile.txt for me
just in case,you wont be able to find the files that dont have required privileges from your user
but if i use sudo find / i will right?
yes
thats false cuz i used sudo and still its not going in deep
everytime it works for me :D
wach time
when you specify / to find, find automatically searches the subdirs too
